As a first-time F1 game player, I actually had a really good time. It’s definitely worth trying if you’re into F1 and want something that feels a bit arcade-like but still has some sim elements. It’s not on the level of iRacing or Assetto Corsa, but it has its own strengths.

The game is easy to play with friends, and it’s nice to see a co-op career mode included. Breaking Point is also a great addition, giving players a story to follow and challenges to complete.

My Team is honestly awesome. I enjoy it way more than the regular driver career mode. The recent AI update improved things, although the AI is still too slow on corner entry.

Overall, I hope the series keeps improving, and I’m looking forward to seeing what F1 26 brings.
It feels better than F1 24, but it still makes you miss the 2020 game. In online races with your friends, you can enjoy the game to the fullest.
In real life, Ferrari can't find their way to the podium. In this game? I can make them champions.
Best game overall since F1 20, easy to drive even on controller.

I would love it for preset helmets for teams | Stickers to put on your helmet without mods, like the Unicorn Sticker, Mobil 1, Visa, Ect, just like how you can customize the car in My Team, just like in Nascar 25 for example, you can customize pretty much everything in your career in that game, and also add more customize options for My team. Helmets, Livery, Ect. That's pretty much all I have. Great game. Worth buying

I think it's a nice improvement on the last game. The car feels much better to drive, the game looks nicer and runs pretty alright and the new my team 2.0 mode is fun. In terms of AI the game is also a big improvement, I never played any of the older F1 games but it's definitely a lot better than F1 24 on the difficulty that i play against (100-110 depending on the track)  However not much else has really changed in terms of gameplay, still the same driver career mode and F1 World is still just kind of pointless, and this is still EA so you better expect some overpriced DLC and cosmetics in the shop.

One of the best F1's out there, the game is genuinely fun and enjoyable to play. I really like the physics improvement, the way the car handles feels satisfactory. The tire simulation is not the best, but it is pretty solid, and the dirt air really punishes on this game. It's not a full sim title like Assetto and iRacing, but it's fun and doesn't demand a lot of concentration like the titles i mentioned before. The online is a mess and thats why it's awesome (not a mess in technical way, the players are just completly insane or full sweats). I really recommend picking it up during the sale (the full price is a bit expensive). All the modes are incredibly fun and thinking about having 2 seasons in 1 F1 game (reminds me of F1 2015) adds a cool and immersive touch to career mode.
Learning more about the f1 sport via this game... Everything is good so far!!!!!
Can do better but compare to 24 I see upgrades here so, keep up Codemaster, before saying goodbye.

F1 25 brings a noticeable improvement in handling, AI behaviour, and overall gameplay polish. The Standard Edition gives you the full experience without needing the Iconic pack. Career mode feels solid, graphics look cleaner, and multiplayer is smoother this year. Still has a few bugs and AI inconsistencies, but overall it’s a fun and worthy upgrade for F1 fans.

Handling is the best it's been in years. Optimised well and looks great.

AI is decent enough but difficulty sliders seem to just make one or two drivers insanely quick and not the rest.
Yes it is very nice good game and they are extending it for another year.
best f1 game to be released after f1 2020, game is really fun and the car handling is very good this game

F1 25 gets a lot of things right. The gameplay is a big step up from the previous entry more responsive, more dynamic, and overall much more fun again. I also appreciate the decision to release F1 26 as a DLC, giving the developers more time to focus on F1 27.

The continuation of the Braking Point story is well done, too, building nicely on the previous chapter.

Overall, it's a strong update to the series and an easy recommendation for any F1 fan.

Awesome game, for F1 fans with real voice overs and visuals of tracks.

F1 2025 takes the racing sim to new heights with stunning graphics, refined gameplay, and immersive features. The game’s visuals are breathtaking, with realistic car models, dynamic weather, and lifelike tracks that bring the sport to life.

The gameplay strikes a perfect balance between realism and accessibility. The physics system has been upgraded, and weather effects now impact handling, making every race unpredictable. The revamped AI feels more natural, with opponents making smarter, race-driven decisions.

Career Mode has been expanded, offering deeper team management and personal rivalries. You can now develop your car, manage budgets, and face contract negotiations, adding layers of strategy to the experience.

Multiplayer remains top-notch, with smooth online racing and fun live events. The sound design is spot on, capturing the roar of engines and track ambiance perfectly.

Overall, F1 2025 is a thrilling and polished racing game that sets a new standard for the series.

F1 25 feels like the series finally found its balance again. The handling is the first thing that stood out to me — the cars feel more planted and predictable compared to the last couple of games. When you push into a corner, you actually feel the grip building or disappearing instead of the car suddenly snapping. It makes driving fast way more enjoyable.

Visually, the game looks great. Tracks feel more alive, lighting is cleaner, and racing in the rain is honestly awesome. The spray, the reflections, the way the car struggles for traction — it all feels more believable.

Career Mode is probably where I’ve spent the most time, and it’s solid this year. AI drivers behave more realistically, overtakes make sense, and the weekend progression feels smoother. You can actually see your team getting better over the season rather than random boosts.

Multiplayer has been pretty stable so far. Lobbies load faster, and there’s noticeably less chaos thanks to the improved collision and penalty systems.

It’s not a revolutionary jump, but it’s a genuinely enjoyable step forward. If you’ve been waiting for a more polished and consistent F1 game, F1 25 definitely feels like one of the better entries in recent years.

See, F1 25 is a step up over 24 in a few regards, largely (and impressively) performance. The game runs well on ultrawides and VR and the whole nine yards where its predecessor did not. Codemasters' strong work on the solid base here continues to shine through, but what's kind of nagged at me throughout is I felt consistently like I was waiting for the point where I'd settle in and it would Get Good, and at the 71 hour mark, that should have been earlier than now.

Laser-scanned tracks! That's cool. I could not tell you which of them they laser-scanned, just by like, playing. Reverse tracks! I would love to dunk on how pointless it is that there's only three of them, replacing the usual bonus track from the past few games, but I will say, Reverse Zandvoort kinda slaps.

Braking Point reaches its end with a conclusion that I know I played when this game came out but I could not tell you what happened in it. It is a Sports League Tie-In Story so things can't actually really happen. I will concede that despite myself, I was a lil' emotional over one decision involving a character I'd been playing as in three separate games, so they do deserve some credit on that.

My Team 2.0 is the thing I latched onto, the reason I bought this. Building your HQ, assembling your own car, all the RPG elements cranked up to 11, it really seems fascinating. But it's really incomplete and inconsistent.

In practice, there are *not* countless different builds you can end up with, or competition levels you can be at compared to other cars, like R&D in other games (and modes) in the series. Instead, there are three tiers of Breakthroughs for each department. Functionally, each competitor is thus at one of four levels of competition, and you will be bottlenecked by having to wait for the next Breakthrough *when* you have caught up on all of your R&D really quickly. Not if. It will be when, if you are any degree of competent at it (and I'm not! and I still had that problem!). Between HQ management, tire and engine management, driver and staff management, and car development management, it *should* be that perfect ebb and flow this series is sometimes the pinnacle of, where you do lots of prep, put the car out on the track, and hope it's what you need.

In practice, it is lots and lots of menus and completely pointless jabbering from 3D-modeled advisors that interrupt you constantly, repeating the same few voice lines and animations, getting in the way of running races that feel exactly the same as the rest of the game. As you are no longer an owner/driver, you do pick which driver you play as, but this leaves the mode feeling disconnected or pasted over the existing framework, as you aren't even the same guy when race weekend hits. 

The sponsor decal system feels fantastic and visual customization is immensely better than it's ever been, and even online public lobbies are lovely to look at with incentives to easily whip up something good-looking. Filling the car out with new sponsors over the course of My Team is super satisfying.

As ever, radioing the crew by just pressing a button and then actually speaking feels real dang nice.

The lil' bit of voice clips and the way you're addressed changing when you're playing as one of the actual season drivers is real neat and adds a little something.

There is a wealth of voiceover commentary in this video game, all of which will trigger at the complete wrong times. Your crew will merrily radio in to keep up the good work managing your tires, while they are blowing and firing you into a wall. Davidson will, without fail, every Sprint weekend, first declare "well, they say that a change is as good as a rest..." and then, however you place in the Sprint, start the race day commentary by telling everyone you did amazing and you've got to be riding high after that success *and,* under a second later, that it couldn't have gone much worse, what a shame. It cannot get out of its own way, and I cannot stay immersed for over 20 minutes. All this presentation is supposed to be their one big showy leg up, yeah? It ought to at least be good.

Driver Career is identical to F1 24, except you can also race as or against the APXGP team from the F1 movie- what's that? Sorry? Oh, you didn't order it the month it came out? No, then. You can't do that. Nah, one of the entire playable teams in the game they just removed all way to access. Sorry about that.

You can use any *real* team from the F1 2025 season, though, and you can even select their special liveries from throughout the year- what's that? Oh. No, you can only do that outside of career mode- oh! And you have to have played certain specific online events when they were around. They're gone now, so no, you can't do that.

F1 World has an RPG-esque system, where you can unlock all sorts of upgrades for your multiplayer car. If you don't want those, you can trade them in to unlock pictures for a little F1 history scrapbook- what's that? Oh, that was F1 24. I see. In this one, you can trade them in to get... extremely small amounts of in-game currency usable only for buying more parts for the same mode. Okay.

This is a game starving for a coherent vision and content, and it is rapidly losing both the longer it's out. If you purchase it now, you will be getting an actively worse, lesser game than when it released, and it needed help when it released. I really, really want to love it. When it fires on all cylinders, you catch glimpses of a beautifully assembled game. However, it does not do that for over a couple minutes at a time.

But...that's if you can get it to load.  The load times in best case scenarios are incredibly long, including when just trying to quit the game.  For example, starting the game, loading the menu, then loading a race can take 7-8 minutes.  Worst case, the game constantly crashes when trying to start, and with the load time issue, it's nearly impossible to tell if the game will ever load.

Along with that, it's an EA product, meaning it's constantly trying to advertise and upsell you.  Popups whenever going to the main menu trying to tell you about their latest package you can pay money for.

Overall, I liked the actual racing, but the wrapper around it was just too much of a pain to deal with.

You can literally try to push them off track and they barely move, yet they touch you and your in the wall. Apparently it's to do with their simple physics/traction model, but when you're trying to race wheel to wheel, you are literally on a knifes edge...
Then there's the public multiplayer modes... unless you like being sent to the shadow realm with no repercussions for the perpetrator, jump on a public lobby... there is absolutely no inkling of good racing there. just f-wits and griefers.
Once my 2 Player season is over, i'll be uninstalling and switching to another racing game, then await the 2026 DLC, for next F1 season.

F1 25 is a complete disappointment for VR users. I genuinely want a refund. I bought this specifically to play in VR, but after countless attempts, the game refuses to launch properly in VR at all. I tried every setup method, launch option, runtime, and hotkey trick out there, and nothing works.

I tested both OpenXR and SteamVR, added launch options like -vr and -steamvr, tried forcing VR through command lines, toggled OpenXR runtimes, and even adjusted hotkeys to switch display modes. The result is the same. The game either boots flat on monitor, gets stuck, or fails to initialise VR entirely. A AAA racing title should not require players to go through hours of technical trial and error just to start a race.

The VR implementation feels untested and unstable. Hotkeys don’t respond, the game keeps fighting over VR runtime selection, and there is no clean way to launch directly into VR without breaking something else. I never managed to start a single proper VR session.

EA needs to urgently fix F1 25’s VR launch process, hotkey conflicts, and the messy OpenXR/SteamVR integration. At this point, this is a one star product for VR players. Broken at launch, not user friendly, and absolutely not worth the money until they patch it.

If you're a VR player give this a miss. I can play F1 2023 in VR and it's crisp and smooth. This game has wildly varying frame rates that will make you feel unwell no matter how seasoned a VR player you are and many of the options you would normally expect to be able to tweak are missing, notably no DLSS options in VR but it is there in non-VR so the engine does implement it (and I read that it was there on release but was later patched out as they couldn't get it to work in VR) and no control over how blurry the TAA mode is which is strange as TAA is usually quite crisp. Reducing render scale has very little effect on the performance and makes an already blurry game almost illegible (hard to spot an apex when its a fuzzy blur). There is also an issue with stuttering when you move your head around that EA acknowledge but only plan to fix in a "future F1 release" cause they've got to crack on with getting next years fresh cash grab out the door instead of supporting this trash.
